contextId.information: "Get the road ready for the Lord." Doing this represents being prepared to hear the Lord's message when he comes. People do this by repenting of their sins. AT: "Prepare to hear the Lord's message when he comes" or "Repent and be ready for the Lord to come" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Make ready the way of the Lord

contextId.information: This is a metaphor. Here "offspring" means "having the characteristic of." Poisonous snakes are dangerous and represent evil. This can be stated as a separate sentence. AT: "You evil poisonous snakes! Who" or "You are evil like poisonous snakes! Who" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You offspring of poisonous snakes, who

contextId.information: The phrase "bear fruit" is a metaphor referring to a person's actions. AT: "Let your actions show that you have truly repented" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Bear fruit worthy of repentance

contextId.information: This metaphor means Simon and Andrew will teach people God's true message, so others will also follow Jesus. AT: "I will teach you to gather men to me like you used to gather fish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I will make you fishers of men

contextId.information: This metaphor means a person should strongly desire to do what is right. AT: "desire to live right as much as they desire food and drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: hunger and thirst for righteousness

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) just as salt makes food good, a disciple of Jesus must influence the people of the world so that they will be good. AT: "You are like salt for the people of the world" or 2) just as salt preserves food, a disciple of Jesus must keep people from becoming totally corrupt. AT: "As salt is for food, you are for the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]).
contextId.quote: You are the salt of the earth

contextId.information: This means Jesus' followers bring the message of God's truth to all the people who do not know God. AT: "You are like a light for the people of the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You are the light of the world

contextId.information: This means a disciple of Jesus should live in such a way that others can learn about God's truth. AT: "Let your lives be like a light that shines before people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Let your light shine before people

contextId.information: "not even the smallest written letter or the smallest part of a letter. This is a metaphor referring to something in the scriptures that may not seem to be important. AT: "not even the laws that seem unimportant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: not one jot or one tittle

contextId.information: This metaphor indicates that a man who lusts after a woman is as guilty of adultery as a man who actually commits the act of adultery. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: everyone who looks on a woman to lust after her has already committed adultery with her in his heart

contextId.information: Here "eye" refers to what a person sees. And, "stumble" is a metaphor for "sin." AT: "if what you see causes you to stumble" or "if you want to sin because of what you see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: If your right eye causes you to stumble

contextId.information: This metaphor means to do something that purposefully gets people's attention. AT: "do not draw attention to yourself like someone who plays a loud trumpet in a crowd" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: do not sound a trumpet before yourself

contextId.information: This is a metaphor for total secrecy. Just as hands usually work together and can be said to "know" what each other is doing at all times, you should not let even those closest to you know when you are giving to the poor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing

contextId.information: A debt is what one person owes another. This is a metaphor for sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: debts

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that means do good things on earth so God will reward you in heaven. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: store up for yourselves treasures in heaven

contextId.information: This compares healthy eyes that allow a person to see to diseased eyes that cause a person to be blind. This is a metaphor referring to spiritual health. Often Jewish people used the phrase "bad eye" to refer to greed. The meaning is: if a person is completely devoted to God and sees things the way he does, then they are doing what is right. If a person is greedy for more, then he is doing what is evil. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The eye is the lamp of the body ... how great is that darkness

contextId.information: This does not refer to magic. Jewish people often used this as a metaphor for someone who is greedy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: if your eye is bad

contextId.information: This is a metaphor for a person's most important faults. A log could not literally go into a person's eye. Jesus is emphasizing that a person should pay attention to his own more important faults before he deals with another person's less important faults. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: the log that is in your own eye

contextId.information: Jews considered these animals dirty, and God told the Jews not to eat them. They are metaphors for wicked people who do not value holy things. It would be best to translate these words literally. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: dogs ... hogs

contextId.information: These are metaphors for praying to God. The verb form shows that we are to keep praying until he answers. If your language has a form for continuing to do something over and over, use it here. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Ask ... Seek ... Knock

contextId.information: This is an image of a person traveling on a road and entering into a kingdom through a gate. One kingdom is easy to enter; the other is hard to enter. This is a metaphor that means a person must accept the more difficult life of obeying God to receive eternal life. If they choose an easier life of not obeying God, they will enter into hell. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Enter through the narrow gate ... few who find it

contextId.information: This metaphor means false prophets will pretend like they are good and want to help you, but they are really evil and will do you harm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who come to you in sheep's clothing but are truly ravenous wolves

contextId.information: Jesus continues to use the metaphor of fruit to refer to bad prophets who produce evil works. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the bad tree produces bad fruit

contextId.information: Jesus continues to use fruit trees as a metaphor to refer to false prophets. Here, he only states what will happen to the bad trees. It is implied that the same thing will happen to the false prophets. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Every tree that does not produce good fruit is cut down and thrown into the fire

contextId.information: The word "their" can refer to either the prophets or the trees. This metaphor implies that the fruit of trees and the deeds of prophets both reveal whether they are good or bad. If possible, translate this in a way so that it can refer to both trees and prophets. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: you will recognize them by their fruits

contextId.information: Jesus does not mean literally that dead people will bury other dead people. Possible meanings of "the dead": 1) it is a metaphor for those who will soon die, or 2) it is a metaphor for those who do not follow Jesus and are spiritually dead. The main point is that a disciple must not let anything delay him from following Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: leave the dead to bury their own dead

contextId.information: This is a metaphor comparing the entire nation of Israel to sheep who have strayed from their shepherd (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: lost sheep of the house of Israel

contextId.information: Jesus is using this as a metaphor for himself. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the master of the house

contextId.information: This is a metaphor for Jesus' disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: his household

contextId.information: Here "daylight" means "in public." AT: "say openly" or "say publicly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: say in the daylight

contextId.information: This does not mean the person will die. It is a metaphor that means the person will not experience spiritual life with God. AT: "will not have true life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will lose it

contextId.information: This metaphor means the person will experience spiritual life with God. AT: "will find true life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will find it

contextId.information: Possible meanings are 1) Jesus mean the literal plants by the Jordan River or 2) Jesus is using a metaphor to mean a kind of person. AT: "a man who easily changes his mind and is like a reed blowing back and forth in the wind" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: a reed being shaken by the wind

contextId.information: Jesus is speaking about the people as if they are animals, which their masters have made to carry too much weight on their backs. This is a metaphor for all the laws and rules the Jewish leaders expect the people to obey. AT: "who labor under all the laws the religious leaders place on you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: who labor and are heavy burdened

contextId.information: Jesus continues the metaphor. Jesus is inviting the people to become his disciples and follow him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Take my yoke on you

contextId.information: Jesus is using a metaphor that refers to a person either gathering the flock of sheep to a shepherd or making them scatter away from the shepherd. Jesus means that a person is either helping to make people become disciples of Jesus or he is making people reject Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the one who does not gather with me scatters

contextId.information: Here "offspring" means "having the characteristic of." Vipers are poisonous snakes that are dangerous and represent evil. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:03:07|3:7]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You offspring of vipers

contextId.information: Jesus speaks about the "heart" as if it is a container that a person fills with good or evil things. This is a metaphor that means what a person says reveals what the person is truly like. If you want to keep this imagery see the UDB. You can also translate the literal meaning. AT: "A man who is truly good will speak good things, and the man who is truly evil will speak evil things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: The good man from the good treasure of his heart produces what is good, and the evil man from the evil treasure of his heart produces what is evil

contextId.information: Here "adulterous" is a metaphor for people who are not faithful to God. AT: "unfaithful generation" or "godless generation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: adulterous generation

contextId.information: This is a metaphor for the person in whom the unclean spirit was living. AT: "to the place I left" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to my house from which I came

contextId.information: Again, "house" is a metaphor for the person in whom the unclean spirit was living. Here, "swept out and put in order" suggests that no one is living in the house. Jesus means when an unclean spirit leaves a person, the person must invite the Holy Spirit to live in him or else the demon will come back. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: that house swept out and put in order

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that means Jesus' disciples belong to Jesus' spiritual family. This is more important than belonging to his physical family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: here are my mother and my brothers

contextId.information: Here "see" represents understanding.  AT: "they do not understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they do not see

contextId.information: Here "hear" represents listening well. AT: "they do not listen well" or "they do not pay attention" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they do not hear

contextId.information: In 13:15 God describes the people of Israel as if they have physical diseases that cause them to be unable to learn, to see, and to hear. God wants them to come to him so he will heal them. This is all a metaphor describing the people's spiritual condition. It means the people are stubborn and refuse to receive and understand God's truth. If they would, then they would repent and God would forgive them and welcome them back as his people. If the meaning is clear, keep the metaphor in your translation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For this people's heart ... I would heal them

contextId.information: "have me heal them." This means God would heal them spiritually by forgiving their sins and receiving them again as his people.  AT: "have me receive them again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: I would heal them

contextId.information: Jesus speaks of Satan causing the person to forget what he has heard as if he were a bird snatching the seed from the ground. AT: "The evil one causes him to forget the message that he has heard just like a bird that snatches away seed from the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the evil one comes and snatches away what has been sown in his heart

contextId.information: Jesus speaks about the cares of the world and the deceitfulness of riches distracting a person from obeying God's word as if they were weeds that could wind around a plant and keep it from growing.  AT: "as weeds prevent good plants from growing, the cares of the world and the deceitfulness of riches keep this person from listening to God's word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the cares of the world and the deceitfulness of riches choke the word

contextId.information: The person is spoken of as if he were a plant. AT: "Like a healthy plant that bears a crop of fruit, he is productive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He bears fruit and makes a crop

contextId.information: This is a metaphor for the fires of hell. If the term "furnace" is not known, "oven" can be used. AT: "fiery furnace." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:40|13:42]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: furnace of fire

contextId.information: Jesus uses another metaphor to describe the Pharisees. Jesus means that the Pharisees do not understand God's commands or how to please him. Therefore, they cannot teach others how to please God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: blind guides ... both will fall into a pit

contextId.information: This is a metaphor comparing the entire nation of Israel to sheep who have strayed from their shepherd. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:10:05|10:6]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to the lost sheep of the house of Israel

contextId.information: The woman responds by using the same imagery as Jesus used in the proverb he just spoke. She means non-Jews should be able to have a small amount of the good things Jews are throwing away. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: even the little dogs eat some of the crumbs that fall from their masters' tables

contextId.information: Here "adulterous" is a metaphor for people who are not faithful to God. AT: "unfaithful generation" or "godless generation." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:12:38|12:39]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: An evil and adulterous generation

contextId.information: Here "yeast" is a metaphor that refers to evil ideas and wrong teaching. Translate as "yeast" here and do not explain its meaning in your translation. This meaning will be made clear in 16:12. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees

contextId.information: Here "yeast" represents evil ideas and wrong teaching. Translate as "yeast" and do not explain the meaning in your translation. In 16:12 the disciples will understand the meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the yeast of the Pharisees and Sadducees

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that means Peter will be the leader for the community of people who believe in Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: upon this rock I will build my church

contextId.information: Here "Hades" is spoken of as if it were a city surrounded by walls with gates that keep dead people in and other people out. Here "Hades" represents death, and its "gates" represent its power. Possible meanings are 1) "the powers of death will not overcome my church" or 2) "my church will break down the power of death the way an army breaks into a city." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The gates of Hades will not prevail against it

contextId.information: Here "keys" represent Jesus giving Peter authority. This does not make Peter the owner of the kingdom, but he has authority to decide who will enter God's kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the keys of the kingdom of heaven

contextId.information: This metaphor means that God in heaven will approve of what Peter allows or forbids on earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: bind on earth shall be bound in heaven ... loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven

contextId.information: Jesus means that Peter is acting like Satan because Peter is trying to prevent Jesus from accomplishing what God sent him to do. AT: "Get behind me, because you are acting like Satan! You are a stumbling block to me" or "Get behind me, Satan! I call you Satan because you are a stumbling block to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Get behind me, Satan! You are a stumbling block to me

contextId.information: Following Jesus here represents being one of his disciples. AT: "be my disciple" or "be one of my disciples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: follow me

contextId.information: This does not mean the person must necessarily die. It is a metaphor that means the person will consider obeying Jesus as being more important than his own life. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will lose it

contextId.information: This metaphor means the person will experience spiritual life with God. AT: "will find true life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: will find it

contextId.information: This metaphor means that God in heaven will approve of what Peter allows or forbids on earth. See how you translated these in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:16:19|16:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: bind ... bound ... release ... released

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that emphasizes the unity of a husband and a wife. AT: "and they will become like one person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: and the two will become one flesh

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that emphasizes the unity of a husband and a wife. AT: "So a husband and wife are no longer like two persons, but they are like one person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: So they are no longer two, but one flesh

contextId.information: The word "ransom" usually refers to setting someone free from prison or slavery. Here it is a metaphor for Jesus saving people from God punishing them for their sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: as a ransom for many

contextId.information: Jesus uses a metaphor to scold the people for buying and selling items in the temple. AT: "like a place where robbers hide" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: den of robbers

contextId.information: Here, "this stone" is the same stone as in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:21:42|21:42]]. This is a metaphor that means the Christ will destroy anyone who rebels against him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The stone will break into pieces anyone who falls on it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Whoever falls on this stone will be broken to pieces

contextId.information: Here "burdens" are the many rules that the religious leaders create. AT: "they make you obey many rules that are difficult to follow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: they bind heavy burdens that are difficult to carry, and then they put them on people's shoulders

contextId.information: The Jewish leaders were spiritually blind. Although they thought of themselves as teachers, they were unable to understand God's truth. See how you translated "blind guides" in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:15:12|15:14]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: blind guides ... blind fools

contextId.information: "is tied to his oath." Being required to do what one has said he would do in an oath is spoken of as if he is tied to the oath. AT: "must do what he promised to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is bound to his oath

contextId.information: "is tied to his oath." Being required to do what one has said he would do in an oath is spoken of as if he is tied to the oath. AT: "must do what he promised to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: is bound to his oath

contextId.information: Jesus uses this metaphor to describe the Pharisees. Jesus means that the Pharisees do not understand God's commands or how to please him. Therefore, they cannot teach others how to please God. See how you translated this metaphor in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:15:12|15:14]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You blind guides

contextId.information: Being careful to follow the less important laws and ignoring the more important laws is as foolish as being careful not to swallow the smallest unclean animal but eating the meat of the largest unclean animal either purposely or unknowingly. AT: "you are as foolish as a person who strains out a gnat that falls into his drink but swallows a camel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
contextId.quote: you who strain out a gnat but swallow a camel

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that means the scribes and Pharisees appear pure on the outside to others, but on the inside they are wicked. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: For you clean the outside of the cup and of the plate, but inside they are full of greed and self-indulgence

contextId.information: The Pharisees were spiritually blind. Although they thought of themselves as teachers, they were unable to understand God's truth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You blind Pharisee

contextId.information: Jesus uses this as a metaphor meaning the Pharisees will complete the wicked behavior that their forefathers started when they killed the prophets. AT: "You also finish the sins your ancestors began" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: You also fill up the measure of your fathers

contextId.information: Jesus is speaking to Jerusalem as if it is a woman and the people are her children. AT: "your people" or "your inhabitants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: your children

contextId.information: This refers to the pains a woman feels before giving birth to a child. This metaphor means these wars, famines, and earthquakes are just the beginning of the events that will lead to the end of the age. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: the beginning of birth pains

contextId.information: "close to the gates." Jesus uses the imagery of a king or important official getting close to the gates of a walled city. It is a metaphor meaning the time for Jesus to come is soon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: at the very gates

contextId.information: This is a metaphor that means the Son of Man will separate all people. He will put the righteous people at his right side, and he will put the sinners at his left side. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: He will place the sheep on his right hand, but the goats on his left
